episode.title: Stoneridge Investment Partners, LLC v. Scientific-Atlanta, Inc.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 06-43, Stoneridge Investment Partners v. Scientific-Atlanta, et al..
Mr. Grossman.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The text of section 10(b) as well as the rule 10b-5 promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission prohibit the use of any deceptive device by any person, indirectly or indirectly, in connection with the purchase or sale of a security.
The various deceptive devices used by the Respondents in this case is conduct that is squarely covered by the text of the statute and by the rule.
Respondents here were not passive bystanders facilitating a fraud by Charter.
Their deceptive conduct was integral to the scheme to create fictitious advertising revenues for Charter to report to investors.
Respondents agreed to overcharge Charter so that they could receive the money from Charter to then return to it for the advertising, using Charter's very--
same money for the purchase of the advertising.
Respondent Scientific-Atlanta created a document falsely claiming that the reason for the increased payments from Charter were because of increased manufacturing expenses.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The transaction was not wholly without benefit to Scientific-Atlanta.
They got some advertising.
And it was not wholly without benefit to Charter.
They were able to show that advertising works.
Now, that puts aside the fact that they were using misleading accounting principles.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Well, I would agree, Your Honor, that they received free advertising.
But the problem was that they were creating the illusion that it wasn't free advertising, but rather that they were purchasing the advertising.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And was the price four to five times higher than the normal rates for advertising?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: That is correct, Justice Ginsburg.

And the obvious purpose for creating the illusion that they were purchasing the advertising rather than receiving free advertising was so that Charter can incorporate these increased revenues in their financial statements.
And Respondents understood,--

they understood that in order to... for Charter to pass this by their accountants, to deceive the accountants... and this is reflected in the indictment... in order to deceive the accountants for Charter, the Respondents were told that there had to be separate agreements for both the advertising agreements and the purchase agreements.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Grossman, is there any reason why, in principle, the elements for a cause of action under 10b-5 have to be the same as the elements for a cause of action by the agency under 10(b)?
I mean, we, we created this, this cause of action.
It's not set forth in the statute, although other private causes of action are.
If it's our creation, couldn't we sensibly limit it so that, for example, schemes can be attacked by the SEC, but schemes do not form the basis for private attorney general's actions?
You need actual conveyance of a misrepresentation to the injured party.
Is there any reason why we couldn't do that?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Well, I think there are two reasons, Your Honor.
The first is that at this point in time... I think as the Court recognized in Dura fairly recently... that when Congress enacted the Private Security Law Reform Act, that at that time they accepted--
the private right of action that this Court had previously inferred.
And this Court had previously inferred the private right of action not only for the section but each of the rules in Section 10(b).

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But it's not like under the Sherman Act, where we have reason to think Congress intended the Court to go about the business of construing and developing antitrust law.
In fact, they have kind of taken over for us.
They are imposing certain limits on when actions can be brought, proposing particular specific elements.
In one of the provisions, 20(e), specifying the SEC can bring an action but private investors can't.
I mean, we don't get in this business of implying private rights of action any more.
And isn't the effort by Congress to legislate a good signal that they have kind of picked up the ball and they are running with it and we shouldn't?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Well, this Court, Your Honor, as recently as 2002 in Wharf (Holdings) said there is a private right of action for violation of any of the subdivisions of rule 10b-5: a, b, or c.
That would have to be reversed.
Going back to the Superintendent of Insurance case in, in... that would be in 1971, Your--
Honor, the Court held there was a private right of action for violation of--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's kind of my point.
We did that sort of thing in 1971.
We haven't done it for quite sometime.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --But when Congress enacted the Private Security Law Reform Act, everything it did in connection with that statute was directed to the private right of action that this Court had previously implied under 10(b).
Nothing that Congress did was intended in any way--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I'm not... my suggestion is not that we should go back and say that there is no private right of action.

My suggestion is that we should get out of the business of expanding it, because Congress has taken over and is legislating in the area in a way they weren't back when we implied the right of action under 10(b).

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, I would agree, Congress has taken it over.
And when they enacted the Private Security Law Reform Act, they recognized this private right of action.
Everything they did recognized the private right of action.
It recognized that there would be multiple primary violators of 10(b).
It did that in connection with proportionate liability--
provisions.
It recognized that there would be multiple players.
So certainly, Congress had an understanding of what this Court had done up until that time.
And this Court up until that time had implied the private right of action for every subset of rule 10b-5.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Is it... is it a necessary part of your theory that the deceptive practice that Scientific-Atlanta went in, that they knew that that was also... that Charter would carry that forward?

I mean, let's suppose that there were benefits to this deceptive practice to Scientific-Atlanta, that it looked like it had more money to spend on advertising than it really did, but they didn't care what Charter did with it.
In fact, they didn't know that Charter was going to carry it on its books the way they did.
Would there still be liability for Scientific-Atlanta?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.

No, not under the test that we have proposed, which is very similar to the test proposed by the Ninth Circuit or applied in the Ninth Circuit in the Simpson case, and the test proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in their amicus brief submitted in the Simpson case.
It's not enough to just to have the deceptive act.
The deceptive act for scheme liability has to be with the purpose of--
furthering a scheme to defraud investors.

So if Scientific-Atlanta or Motorola had engaged in deceptive conduct, but that deceptive conduct was not intended to further a scheme to defraud the shareholders, no, Your Honor, there would be no action under the theory that we are pursuing here.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Intended or known?
I mean, I don't see... what's in it for Scientific-Atlanta to defraud the shareholders?
Is it enough that they just knew it would be used for that purpose?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Oh, it would be enough if they committed a deceptive act and they knew it was in furtherance of a scheme.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, when you say "in furtherance of", you... you import intent.
They didn't care what Charter was going to do with it, but they pretty well knew that what Charter was going to do was to make its books look better.
Would that be enough?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: I think that would be reckless.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's what I thought your position was.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Yes, but my position is also--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So it's not an intent necessarily.
It's just knowledge.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --It certainly needs scienter.
You certainly need scienter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I mean, it's more than knowledge.
I mean, you mentioned recklessness.
It's got to have either knowledge of or a willingness to maintain an indifference to the consequence.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Exactly right, Justice Souter.

And I think it's important... and there is a very... there is a very good discussion of this in the Simpson case by the Ninth Circuit, that the purpose of the test is such that it will not ensnare someone who does engage in a deceptive act but doesn't understand that the reason for it is to further a scheme.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Sure.
After trial... you know, after trial which causes your stock to tank, you may indeed be able to show that you didn't know it was going to be used for that purpose.
I mean, that's what this is all about, isn't it, getting it... getting it by the summary-judgment stage?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.
I think, Your Honor, that this Court answered this last term in the Tellabs case.
And Congress answered that question that you pose in the PSLRA, the Private Security Law Reform Act, so--
that you cannot just bring a case and hope to get it by the summary-judgment stage.

You have to have particularized facts alleged under the heightened pleading standards of the PSLRA and this Court's decision in Tellabs showing that not only the deceptive act, but that the purpose of that deceptive act was to further a scheme.
So, no, you can't just--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What facts... what has to be alleged short of... on information and belief the defendant knew that... that this information would appear on the balance sheets and be used to improve the status of the stock?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, of course if you just... if you just allege it on information and belief, you're out of court.
No doubt about that.
That doesn't pass the heightened pleading standard in Tellabs or the PSLRA.
What you do need is what we have here.

Here you have allegations... and we didn't make these allegations from whole cloth... these allegations were derived principally from a grand jury... the Federal grand jury indictment against Charter executives.
That indictment says that Respondents were informed and ordered to deceive Charter's accountants.
They had to have--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why shouldn't we be--
guided by what Congress did in reaction to the Central Bank case?
There we said there's no aiding-and-abetting liability, Congress amended the statute in 20(e) to say yes, there is, but private plaintiffs can't sue on that basis.
Why shouldn't that inform how we further develop the private action under 10b-5?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, I think if Congress intended under 20(e)... certainly the private actions similar to this... it would have said that only the SEC has the authority to bring a claim for substantial assistance whether or not it involves deceptive conduct.
They could have very easily said "any deceptive conduct", and that would have barred these claims.
They chose not to do that.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But they were... they were addressing a very specific decision from this Court, the Central Bank decision.

And the one thing they did not do is say that that decision was wrong with respect to private... or going forward they weren't going to overrule that decision with respect to private rights of action.
You're asking us to extend to non... I know you call it a primary violator, but not the person who--

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Secondary actors.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --who put the--
deceptive conduct into the market.
You're asking us to extend that liability to them, which seems inconsistent with Congress's approach in 20(e).

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: We are not asking any extension.
Quite the contrary, Your Honor.
I think that is the Respondents who are asking for a narrowing.
When Congress addressed the PSLRA it addressed all of the arguments that we are hearing today from Respondents and their amici.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Is your theory dependent on the proposition that Scientific-Atlanta and Motorola deceived Arthur Andersen?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: That certainly is a large part of it.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: But didn't you allege exactly the opposite in your complaint?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.
We... I think what you're referring to is that... is that the accountants should have conducted a more diligent audit than they did.
I mean these people clearly were trying to deceive the auditors.
Why else would you issue a document falsely stating a reason for a price increase?

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm looking at paragraph 218 of your amended complaint, 109a of the joint appendix, subsection 4.
It says, speaking of--
Arthur Andersen,

"though aware that Charter was seeking to boost its revenues by paying vendors higher prices at the same time it received additional advertising from the same vendors, Andersen failed to properly audit these transactions by confirming them with the vendors. "
So you alleged that they weren't deceived.
You alleged that they knew exactly what was going on.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No... no, Your Honor, they knew that they were paying the vendors higher prices, but they didn't know why.

The contract... the contract for the higher prices was followed by this misstatement saying the reason for the higher prices is because of increased manufacturing expenses, when in fact that wasn't the reason.
The reason was to take money--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Who told... who told Charter that it was necessary for them to have a time spread between the contract... the $20 above the contract price and the advertising payment?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Arthur Andersen.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, if it told them that, didn't it have... it sounds to me from that that the accountant says, look, if you want to make this appear on the balance sheet as though the advertising revenues were just ordinary advertising revenues, you better separate these two.
That suggests that Arthur--
Andersen knew all along what was going on.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.
Justice Ginsburg, what Arthur Andersen did not know... and this is very clear.
They did not know that it was Charter's own money that was being used by the Respondents to purchase the advertising.
They were deceived by that document that said, we are increasing the price on the set-top boxes because of increased manufacturing expense.
That was false.
The reason they were increasing it is because Charter was delivering the money to them.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's exactly the thing they told them to separate.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Well, not for that reason, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What other reason?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: The reason is as follows.
This is what they refer to as barter contracts, two companies exchanging things, which is perfectly legitimate, there's nothing wrong with that.

And there are certain ways to account for it properly, and what Arthur Andersen was telling Charter was in order to be able to have revenues included, gross revenues, you have to have unrelated... unrelated contracts.
They couldn't be a barter transaction.
But there is no way... no way that you could recognize the advertising revenues if--
you're using Charter's own money, and that's what Arthur Andersen did not do.
It would be no different, Justice Scalia, if Charter delivered a suitcase filled with cash and gave it to them and said okay, buy the advertising from us.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I understand what you're saying.
It seems to me that when you say that they can't be connected, you're saying precisely, you can't be bartering the advertising revenue for the increased money that you're paying.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.
You can barter.
You can barter, it's just a question of how you account for it.
But the bartering is one thing.
I mean, that's one accounting principle relating to bartering, but there is no accounting principle that permits the recording of revenue if you're using the money from the seller.
And that's why they disguised--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: All right, just... just to be clear on this... if Charter and Arthur Andersen and Scientific-Atlanta and Motorola all sat down and cooked up this scheme together and they all knew exactly what was going on, would you have a claim against the Respondents here?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Yes.
And the reason for that, Your Honor, is because the advertising contract--
was a sham, and the advertising contract was a sham because Charter was giving the Respondents the money to buy the advertising.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Then I see absolutely no difference between your test and the elements of aiding and abetting.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: The difference is here we would have conceptual--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Because you just said that it's not necessary for there to be an actual deceptive act on the part of the Respondents.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --There has to be a deception... there is deception.
The deception is you're entering into an advertising contract that presents the illusion that you were purchasing advertising, when in fact you were not purchasing the advertising.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But that's... but that's not the fraud that was imposed upon the market.
The fraud that was imposed on the market was Charter's accounting for the transaction on its books.
Nobody bought or sold stock in reliance upon the way that Scientific-Atlanta and Charter structured their deal.
They did so in reliance on the way that Charter communicated its accounting to the marketplace.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: There was no way... no way--
that that could properly be accounted for, and the Respondents understood that.
And that's why they did what they did, that's what--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But you're saying--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But there are... there are any number of kickbacks and mismanagement and petty frauds that go on in the business, and business people know that any publicly held company's shares are going to be affected by its profits, so I see no limitation to your... to your proposal for liability.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, I think the limitations are as follows, Your Honor.
Number one, there has to be the purpose of furthering a scheme to defraud shareholders.
Number two, the test has an element of materiality, that it cannot be--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I agree with Justice Scalia's earlier comment, I don't think that Scientific-Atlanta and Motorola really cared anything of... one way or the other about the investors.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, that may be that they didn't care about the investors--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: For them the scheme made a certain amount of sense, they didn't really care.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, they may not have cared, but that would be reckless because they certainly--
understood--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But that's far different from having a purpose.
You said they have to have a purpose.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --That's correct.

If you just close your eyes... if somebody comes to you and says, look, we want you to enter into this transaction, it's a phony transaction and we don't care... do whatever you want with that, and they know it's a publicly held corporation and they have every reason to understand that this information--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Which goes back to my earlier question, that most people that engage in frauds on business know that if it's a publicly held corporation, it's going to hurt the price of the shares or affect the price of the shares.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Well, they shouldn't engage in schemes to defraud, that's what Congress intended by section 10.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --But as I understand your argument, it is the difference between aiding and abetting liability on the part of the Respondents and liability as, in effect, as first line principles, is their intent, or at the very least in knowledge that they were committing a deceptive act as part of this--
scheme.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: That they have to commit the deceptive act--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --with the requisite intent.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Now, how many times are parties of the position of Respondents ever going to engage in those acts except with exactly the state of mind that on your judgment makes them principals, rather than aiders and abettors.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: It is not on my judgment.
It has to be pled with the particularity required by the PSLRA.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No.
No, I realize that you have to plead it.
What I'm getting at is: Are you making a distinction that in the real world is not a distinction?
That, in reality, no one is going to do what these Respondents did without the kind of knowledge or intent that makes them, on your theory, principals rather than aiders or abettors?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No, there are cases, I think, Your Honor, where they can engage in deceptive conduct, and there would not be the purpose to defraud shareholders.
For instance, Charter may have come to--
them and said look, do me a favor, says the sales manager.
I want to make my numbers for this period so I can take my wife on a trip to Hawaii that the company will give me.
So the company gives him a phony order, thinking that's the purpose of it.
That's the purpose of the phony order to help this guy along.
Well, you've engaged in a deceptive act.
It may be deceptive under 10(b), but you wouldn't satisfy the "purpose" test, because the purpose--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In other words, it's deceptive but not deceptive in relation to, or for the purpose of, deceiving the... someone like the Petitioner.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, wouldn't it--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But don't aiders and abettors have to have that purpose as well?
What distinguishes... what distinguishes the liability that you propose from aider and abettor liability?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --You have to engage in a deceptive act under 10(b).
10(b) prohibits any deceptive act.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I thought you were telling me that in each case there may be a deceptive act but not a deceptive act in relation to somebody like the Petitioner here.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that's a different answer, I think, from the one you were just giving Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: No.
I... I understood, perhaps mistakenly, from Justice Scalia that there wasn't a deceptive act in your hypothetical.
If there is a deceptive act, then it's prohibited by 10(b), and we move to the next statute--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So any aiding-and-abetting through a deceptive act makes you a principal?
Is that it?
You can't be an aider and abettor by committing or enabling a deceptive act without becoming a principal?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --No.
Not at all.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You cannot?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: You, yourself... you, yourself, have to engage in the deceptive act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Your own deceptive act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, but... but if you do, or if you should have known, you are not an aider and abettor.
You are automatically a principal.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: You may be a principal if you satisfy the other elements of our test, which are serious elements that you have to plead with--
particularity, with the heightened pleading standards, that they have the purpose to further a scheme to defraud.
That's very different--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is it fair to say that all aiders and abettors who commit deceptive acts are principals?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What's the difference?
What separates the two?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: There are tests.
You have to take it the next step further, because whether or not that deceptive act had the purpose and effect of furthering a scheme on investors.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Don't you need that to be an aider or abettor?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: An aider or abettor?
You have to have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If I'm entirely innocent, and I don't--

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --An aider... certainly... certainly, the primary violator in the situation that we are discussing where there are deceptive acts is aiding and abetting.
I mean, if an accountant comes in and deliberately falsifies a financial statement, he is--
giving substantial assistance to the company's statement... the company who is issuing those false statements.
He would be an aider and abettor in that sense.
He is also a primary--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You see, I really thought the difference was that the principal is the one who makes the deceptive representation and obtains money from it.
The aider and abettor is the person who facilitates or enables that deceptive representation, which is what we have here.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you say if you facilitate knowingly and intentionally or even grossly negligently, you are not an aider and abettor, but you're a principal.
I really don't understand what's the line between the two.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: If you facilitate with a deceptive act, then you're a primary violator.
That's what section 10(b) prohibits.
If you facilitate without a deceptive act, then you are an aider and abettor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Grossman, before you finish, there is one statement made by the other side that you are trying to use this... small in comparison to all the fraud that was involved here in order to collect on the entire loss.
That is, you are asserting--
that the vendors are liable for the entire loss when they were just a bit player.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Yes.
We are not seeking that at all, Your Honor.
We... the PSLRA proportionate liability provisions govern this with respect to--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So what are you seeking?
How would you measure your damages?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --We would measure the damages, number one, that flow from this particular scheme.
We would have to first subtract the settlements that have been achieved already, and then the proportionate liability provisions of the PSLRA provide how you make this determination.
You look at the particular nature of their conduct, and you look at the extent to which their particular conduct had a causal relationship with the damages.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Mr. Grossman, I'm conscious of eating into your time but a question... how many chains of this connection can you have?
Let's say Charter was not a publicly traded company, but same thing happened with respect to Scientific-Atlanta, and that made it look valuable to a company that is publicly traded.
So they decided to buy Charter and then that made their profits look better to investors.
Can you--
how many chains in the link can you go?

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: Well, I... I think you can go so long as the person's deceptive conduct has the purpose of furthering a scheme to defraud.
If they engage in some deceptive conduct that was not in furtherance of the scheme to defraud, that's the end of the chain.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Grossman.

turn.speaker: stanley_m_grossman
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M. Grossman
turn.text: --Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Shapiro.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: My friend has just asked the Court to expand an implied cause of action by diluting traditional requirements such as the reliance requirement and by eroding this Court's precedent in the Central Bank case.
The Court has said in the past that it must be very cautious about expanding implied causes of action, but here there are special reasons for caution.
Expanding the implied cause of action would give plaintiff the very thing that Congress said it should not get in section 20(e) of the Exchange Act.
Congress wanted cases like this one to be handled by an expert and disinterested administrative agency.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's if you equate this with aiding-and-abetting, and I think the question is is there a middle category between Charter, who is clearly primarily liable, and Central Bank, that didn't do anything deceptive?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: The Central Bank case, I believe, answers that by saying to be a primary violator you have to satisfy all the prerequisites of 10(b) liability, including reliance, loss causation, the "in-connection-with" standard.
And here plaintiffs fail to meet these tests.
And Congress in 20(e)--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you are saying... I thought your argument, unlike the government's argument, is that there was no deceptive device.
There was no deceptive device.
They simply aided and abetted.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Yes.
That's one of the arguments we make.
It is this case is governed by Central Bank because the defendant did not use or employ deception in connection with a securities transaction.
That exactly describes what Charter did.
Now, what exactly describes what the vendors are alleged to do is what is said in 20(e)... to--
knowingly give substantial assistance to someone else that is misleading an investor.
That fits this case like a glove--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I thought... I agree with Justice Ginsburg.
I thought the "in-connection-with" argument is actually in addition to or separate from an additional argument you made that there was no deceptive statement made here.
I thought that's what you were arguing, and I have problems with that argument because the statute doesn't require a statement.
It requires... conduct suffice.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --We don't make these arguments without reference to each other.
We think all of these statutory terms have to be viewed together.
You have to use deception in connection with securities trading, which these vendors did not do.
That's what Charter did.
And--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You don't defend the position--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would you say that there was deception, standing alone?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Well, we have... we have suggested that that is not true when you're speaking with somebody that knows the facts such as Charter.
Charter understood all these facts.
Charter could have--
accounted for these transactions correctly, itself.
The vendors did that.
They didn't recognize any revenues here.
It was up to Charter to account for these transactions properly.
Congress required it to do that, so it is the speaker here.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But Charter said... vendors, I need you to consummate this fraud on the public.
I can't do it without you.
I've got to have those revenues that you're going to give me through these phony advertising payments at four or five times the usual rate.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, we believe even placing that most pejorative characterization on these facts, which we don't agree are the true facts, that still--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you must assume that they are now.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Assuming that they are, that this is a 20(e) situation where it is alleged that the vendors gave substantial, knowing assistance to somebody who was committing a fraud.
And Congress said that an expert and disinterested administrative agency should decide whether to proceed, because it is so slippery to apply these characterizations.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's if they are... that's if they are aiders and if there are only two--
categories and everyone who is not Charter is an aider and abettor, then you're right.
But if there's a middle category of people who, while not the benefited company... the company that's trying to achieve the deception... but made it possible for that... for that deception to happen.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, you know that's an exact description of Central Bank because there it was alleged that the trustee entered--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --into a secret agreement.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --In Central Bank, it was conceded that the bank engaged in no deceptive act.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Here there is the charge that it did engage in deceptive acts.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --What was conceded was that the bank made no statement to investors, but what was alleged in the complaint and argued in the briefs was that the bank entered into a secret side agreement that enabled the use of a fraudulent prospectus that unleashed securities that were worthless on investors, and investors said, we were depending on our trustee to prevent that from happening.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Now, I take it, though, you--
do not defend the position that there must... for 10(b) liability... that there must have been a statement addressed to investors.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, we... we think that for reliance purposes, there--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, do you--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --the defendant has to communicate with investors.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Would you answer my question first?
Do you take the position that there can be no 10(b) liability without a statement addressed to investors?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: It has to be communicated to the investors and it has to be attributed under the case law to the speaker.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You mean the statement as such or a statement which could not have been made but for the statements of the Respondents must be communicated to the investors?
Which one?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: That... that kind of but-for causation is not sufficient.
That is not reliance.
That kind of--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So are you... so you are saying that there can be no causation and hence, you know... and I think you're going further.
You're saying--
there can be no liability within the description of 10(b) unless there is a statement directly addressed to the investors, is that correct?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --That is one of our submissions, but we also say that the substance of these statements was never communicated to investors.
Only Charter--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Because the whole purpose of it--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --spoke to the investors and never summarized these.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. Shapiro, if--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --If it was communicated to investors that there had been $20 per set box over the regular price, if there had been advertising that was paid for by the very money that Charter gave, then the whole thing would have failed.
So this can work only if the vendors are silent.
Silence and not speech is what counts.
If the vendors communicate anything at all, the whole thing fails.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: But the... the communication, Your Honor, has to be to the market and to investors.
There was no duty to disclose to investors here.
The only communications the vendors made were
"we're raising our prices 6 percent, the date of our contract is August 31st, for the simple reason that it started the very next day.... "

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Was there any--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Was there any economic substance to this?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Oh, of course.
There was economic substance from the vendors' perspective.
They were selling their products at exactly the price that they wanted to receive for those products and they were getting some free cooperative advertising thrown in at the same time.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is it true that the price that they were charging, they did not charge to other customers... the $20 hike?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, it's true because they weren't concerned with that because they weren't paying for it.
Charter was paying for this cooperative... cooperative advertising, the reason being--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it was--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --that Charter had a big interest.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --a sham then, because they said the reason they upped the price $20 a box was--
they... the inflationary conditions, so they had to renegotiate the contract, but didn't renegotiate with any of their other customers.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, from the vendors' perspective, this was a transaction that appeared to be a way to increase cooperative advertising.
It cost the vendors no money.
They were told by Charter that Arthur Andersen had approved the transaction.
That's alleged in the Barford indictment.
Then they went home and talked to their own auditors... how do you account for this unusual transaction?
The auditors said, you cannot record any revenues from the transaction.
They didn't record any revenues.
They expected Charter to do the same thing, to not record revenues--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but that's--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --if that's what the rules required.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --that's not the allegation of the complaint.
I... I thought the allegation of the complaint was that they... they knew that this was a fraud and they participated in the fraud.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, they... they do allege.
I'm merely pointing out that in the Barford--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But I mean that... so that your answer doesn't seem to be... get us very far on a legal point.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Well, we say that if you take the complaint at face value and you don't even consider the Barford indictment that they cite, that it still is a classic example of knowingly giving substantial assistance to someone else that is making misstatements to investors, because these vendors didn't make any misstatement to investors.
Nobody relied on their sales correspondence.
It sat in a file drawer until long after the stock had gone all the way up and come all the way down.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's the essence of the scheme.
You said that they... they are home free because they didn't themselves make any statement to investors.
But they set up Charter to make those statements, to swell its revenues... revenues that it in fact didn't have.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: But Congress's policy judgment here is that the SEC, an expert agency that is impartial, should evaluate a claim of that sort and decide whether to proceed.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's if they are aiders and abettors, which is what Congress covered.
And I--
again go back to, is there another category or is everyone... either Charter, the person whose stock is at stake, the company whose stock is at stake and everyone else is an aider?
I take it that that's your position.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It's either the company whose stock is in question or you're an aider and abettor.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --You are only a primary violator under... under Central Bank if each and every element of 10b-5 liability is satisfied, including reliance on your statement, including the "in-connection-with" test, and including loss causation.
None of those tests are satisfied here, but what is satisfied is section 20(e), which says, did they knowingly give substantial assistance to somebody who is committing a fraud?
And that... that fits this case like a glove--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If we accept--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --if Congress wanted the SEC to address--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --If we accept your theory of the case and we then get another case in which an accountant or an attorney who prepares the statement for publication to the investors and then gives it to--
Charter, and they are before us, could we find liability under 10b-5 as to the accountants and still rule... and still keep our ruling in favor of your client here?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --It really depends on--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And if so, what would--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --on the circumstances.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --And if so, what would be the rationale?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Some attorneys are control persons within corporations, and in-house counsel that drafts the disclosure statement which contains a falsehood may be liable as in the McConville case, which the Court recently considered.
Individuals may be liable--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: How about outside accountants and attorneys who deliberately and directly participate in negotiating... or in drafting the false disclosure statements?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Could they be liable and under your theory of the case, but your client not liable?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --It... it's possible.
Your Honor, at the end of your--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well what about in this--
case?
Let's be specific.
As I understood an earlier answer of yours, the answer was that Arthur Andersen knew what was going on.
If I've... if you are... and as I understand it, that's not what was charged... but if that's correct, Arthur Andersen did know what was going on.
Can Arthur Andersen be held liable under 10b-5--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Absolutely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --whereas your client cannot?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Yes, sir.
The reason--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And the difference is?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --The reason is they issued opinions that were circulated to investors, that were attributed to them and which were authorized by them, and if a lawyer does the same thing, if Steve Shapiro writes an opinion letter and circulates it to investors and it's full of falsehoods--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --I can be held liable for that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --What if Arthur Andersen--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --as a speaker.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --What if Arthur Andersen has a footnote in there saying, this is okay because we have--

this... this letter from I forget which one of the two Respondents it was, saying there's been inflation and therefore we've got to renegotiate the prices and jack them up 20 percent, Arthur Andersen knows that that is false and the Respondent who made it knows that it is false, can the Respondent who made it then be held liable?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Only people who speak to the market--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but doesn't--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --and induce investor reliance.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Yes, but doesn't... doesn't the Respondent in that case know that it is likely that the auditor is going to indicate the basis for its statement, that the transaction is okay--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --and, therefore, isn't it reasonable to suppose that they anticipated that their statement would be communicated to the market?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --That is just aiding and abetting, and in fact Congress dealt with that squarely in section 303--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But there's a communication to the market there--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Oh, yes--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --and there's a reason to expect that communication.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Doesn't that make any difference?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: That is not sufficient.

Congress addressed that in section 303 of Sarbanes-Oxley, and it held that any person... said any person including a vendor that misleads an auditor can be held liable in an SEC proceeding only, not in a private suit.
It excluded private actions.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is the word "only" in there?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is the word "only" in there?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: The word "exclusively" is in there--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In the statute?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --and my--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So you have an independent defense quite apart from... from the construction of 10b-5?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --We rely on 20(e) and 303 of--
Sarbanes-Oxley, and my friend has made the argument--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Which I thought speak about aiders and abettors.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --It's talking about an aider and abettor that misleads an auditor and then--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But is usually--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --the auditor issues a false certification.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --aider and abettor... then again we get back to the question: If there's nothing in this world other than the company that puts out the false statement and the aider and abettor--

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well... oh, no--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --and is there something in between?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Your Honor, there are other persons that are control persons within a company who are liable.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But we're taking those out.
We're talking about independent actors.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Independent actors that don't speak to the markets and cause direct reliance on their own statements are aiders and abettors.
And they are supposed to be dealt with by the SEC, an expert agency.
Now, my... you know, my friend made the--
argument about Sarbanes-Oxley that there's a savings clause in that provision that preserves other remedies.
But if you look at the legislative history, it says explicitly we are preserving SEC remedies.
We want the SEC to pursue these suits.
And Congress refused in 2002 in Sarbanes-Oxley to reinstate the aiding-and-abetting private liability cause of action.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Do you know, Mr. Shapiro, if in the law of torts and the restatement of torts or in other areas of the law there is some third classification that's between aider and abettor in principle?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: I don't know the answer.
Although in these statutes themselves there are such provisions not included in section 10(b).
For example in section 18(a), if you cause some other person to make a false statement in a financial statement, you can be held liable, but they are not invoking it in section 18.
Same thing under section 17.
If you engage in a scheme to cause some falsehood, you can be prosecuted by the government.
But nowhere has Congress said that an individual litigant can bring a claim like that without regard for reliance and "in connection with" and the loss causation test.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Let's assume there is reliance and loss causation.
Let me ask a question very similar to what Justice Ginsburg has posed a couple of times.
She has said is there a third category.
My question is, is there an overlap?
Can there be an overlap?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: No, I don't think there can be.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Because Congress intended in section 20(e) to have an expert agency address these cases and not to have the trial--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Congress intended an expert agency to address solely aiding-and-abetting cases.
My question is if there is an overlap... A, can there be an overlap?
And if so, I don't see why Congress's intent to reserve aiding-and-abetting alone to the agency affects the determination of this case.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --We believe they are separate categories and that Central Bank tells us exactly who the primary violator is.
He is somebody who makes a statement that investors rely on in connection with securities transactions, and that is not these vendors.
That is exactly what section 20(e) addresses and commits--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Could you amend that to--
say... you don't insist that he make a statement that invest... he could engage in a deceptive practice directed at investments?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Absolutely.
Absolutely.
We don't quarrel over that, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: For example, for example, let's assume in this case that Charter said we've, we've got to let the investors know that our cost of doing business is going up, and we want to you make an announcement that you're jacking up your price 20 percent.
In that case there would be primary liability.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why in that case is there not also aiding-and-abetting?
We know perfectly well why they are doing it, and they are doing it solely to aid and abet Charter in its scheme themselves enjoying a wash transaction.
Why isn't that both primary and aiding-and-abetting?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, it's primary because there is the communication to the market that's missing here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: We know it's primary.
Why isn't it also aiding-and-abetting?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: You can call it... both of those things.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If you can call it, why isn't there the kind of overlap which raises the question that Justice Ginsburg has raised?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: You can't have primary liability, which they are asserting here, without the statement to the market.
And it can be a statement by conduct, and it can be by nodding of the head.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So you are saying there can be an overlap but there is no overlap that helps the Petitioner in this case?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Oh, yes.
Nodding the head is the same thing as saying yes.
But it has to be made directly to an investor and cause reliance by that investor.
That's what's missing here.
So there is nothing wrong with the Eighth Circuit's decision.
It didn't address that refinement, because it has no bearing on this case.
So there is no point in reversing the decision.

It has to be affirmed in our view for want of reliance, for want of loss causation, for lack of "in connection with", and because most importantly, Congress intended to remove this category of case and commit it to an expert agency as part of its very important reform effort to deal with excessive litigation that was harming our economy.
This was an important concept for Congress.
And it said it twice: First in the PSLRA in 1995, then in 2002, in the Sarbanes-Oxley law.
And it removed even claims that you mislead an auditor under section 303 of Sarbanes-Oxley.
And there is no savings clause there for private actions.
Congress refused to permit the private actions.
Instead, it permitted the SEC to bring intentional misconduct cases under section 20(e) or negligent misconduct cases under section 303 or under section 13.
And the SEC has a broad panoply of remedies.
It doesn't have to just allege intentional--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Does the SEC distinguish this kind of situation where silence is the essence of the thing for the deceiver, silence not speech?
Does the SEC distinguish this from aiding-and-abetting?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --Well, the SEC's view is the one rejected by the Solicitor General, and that's this purpose-and-effect standard that's been advocated, which we think is hopelessly vague.
And it overrides the reliance requirement.
It overrides the "in connection with" requirement.
And it overrides loss causation, not to mention Central Bank.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Shapiro, what is your strongest case, in your view, for the reliance requirement?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Central Bank itself.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Central Bank itself?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: Because the Court there said that even though the bank did something that was a secret agreement that facilitated the issuer's distribution of a false prospectus and caused all the harm to the shareholders, it was a direct sine qua non cause of all of that harm, that that was merely aiding and abetting, because there was no reliance on anything that the bank stated or anything that the bank had a duty to state because of a fiduciary relationship.
Now, the vendors here are even far more removed from investors than the bank was in Central Bank.
The investors knew about the bank in Central Bank, and they were relying on it to do its job.
But that was not sufficient because it made no statement that the investors relied on.
There is no communication here between these vendors and investors.
There is no way you could--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Shapiro, in your judgment, is the reliance requirement an element of the violation or of the private cause of action?

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: --It's the private cause of action.
An important point, Justice Stevens, because the SEC is not burdened with any of these elusive--
inquiries into but-for causation, speculative questions of indirect reliance; none of that burdens the SEC.
And the SEC also has power to distribute funds to investors.
This is the better mousetrap that Congress prescribed for these kinds of cases.
It didn't want the trial lawyers to bring class actions that always result in settlements.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Shapiro.

turn.speaker: stephen_m_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. Stephen M. Shapiro
turn.text: We thank the Court.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Hungar.

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The court of appeals erred to the extent it held that section 10(b) applies only to verbal misrepresentations or omissions.
But the court correctly held that this Court's decision in Central Bank forecloses Petitioner's claim here.
Like the plaintiff in Central Bank, Petitioner cannot establish reliance, a critical element of the section 10(b) implied right of action.
Neither Petitioner nor the market relied on or was even aware of any deceptive conduct or statement by Respondents--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Hungar, I want to be sure I understand one part of the government's position.
You do take the position that there has a violation of 10b-5?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --We haven't taken a position on that question, Your Honor.
We take the position that there was deceptive conduct alleged.
The... one of the elements of a 10b-5 violation, but not the only element.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Were the other elements present?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: As I say, we have not taken... I mean, materiality, for instance, the "in connection with" requirement, scienter, we haven't addressed those questions and have not taken a position.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you have an opinion as to whether there was a violation of 10(b) in this case?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You don't have an opinion?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: We haven't taken a position, and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I know you haven't taken a--
position, but I was just wondering if you have an opinion?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

We haven't addressed the other elements and those... questions that we have... because there is no need to resolve them in this case and because they weren't resolved by the court of appeals or by the district court, we have chosen to focus on what we think is dispositive and what was raised and decided below, which is reliance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You have not reached opinion as to whether there was a violation of the statute?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Has the SEC publicly taken a position on that question?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: I'm not sure of the answer to that question, Your Honor.

Certainly individual commissioners have given speeches and testified before Congress to the effect that the Commission voted in this case to agree with our position on deception, the position that's expressed in our brief, and by a three-to-two vote to disagree with the position on reliance that is expressed in our brief.
But I don't know that there has been any official SEC Commission--
statement to that effect that's been publicly released.
As I said, the only deceptive conduct that was allegedly committed by Respondents in this case involves the backdating of contracts and the false justifications for the price increase.
That conduct was never disclosed to the market at any time during the class period, and therefore, could not have been relied on by the market or by Petitioners.

And as a consequence, under this Court's decisions in Central Bank and in Basic, reliance cannot be established because the presumption of reliance that Petitioner seeks to invoke requires as a prerequisite to its invocation the existence of a publicly disseminated statement from the defendant that was disseminated to, and therefore, relied on by the market.
That did not happen here with respect to Respondents.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Could the SEC get any monetary recovery for the investors on your theory?
You say yes, it's a deceptive practice, but this belongs in the SEC's bailiwick, not in private suits?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Private suits; obviously they are seeking damages for the decline in the share price.
What could the SEC... suppose it should take up this case... get by way of remedy?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: The SEC is entitled to obtain civil fines, as well as disgorgement remedies.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But there is no disgorgement here because the vendors didn't get anything.
For them it was a wash.

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Well, I don't know... I believe in the, not in this case but in the Adelphia case, which is addressed--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, but this case, disgorgement would not be a remedy.
You say fines, but those would be payable to the government, right?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --If I may... yes, yes and no, I think is the answer to that question; because under the fair funds provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, section 308 of Sarbanes-Oxley, the SEC is authorized to take fines and distribute those... add those to disgorgement relief... and distribute them to investors.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But there would be no disgorgement relief.

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure I can agree with that point.
In the Adelphia matter--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What profits did the vendors get?
For them it was a wash.
They got... what did they have to disgorge?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --Well, they obtained... at least--
it appears that they obtained advertising that presumably had some value, although it didn't cost them anything; and presumably the SEC could seek the value of that advertising.
As I said, in the Adelphia matter where the SEC did pursue the vendors that assisted Adelphia in a somewhat similar transaction, it obtained substantial monetary recoveries from them.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But did they receive something that they then disgorged?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --I believe the allegations were similar to those presented here.

But in any event, certainly the SEC has the authority to proceed in that fashion, and additionally the Justice Department has the ability to proceed criminally and obtain substantial monetary sanctions, either as part of a deferred prosecution agreement, as part of a restitutionary sanction and the like; but the fundamental point is that for the private right of action to apply, as this Court said in Central Bank, all of the elements of the private cause of action must be satisfied with respect to the individual defendant.
That is the line.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Do you agree, do you agree with Mr. Shapiro, what I understood to be his argument, that 20(e), the aider and abettor statute, more or less occupies the field here and there is no--
role for additional 10b-5 liability?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't say that it occupies the field per se, but what it does do is... given the timing of this Court's decision in Central Bank in 1994, followed by Congress's considering the question whether to provide for secondary liability in private actions, and its decision not to authorize such secondary liability... what it does clearly suggest is that this Court ought not adopt the expansive view of the implied right of action that Petitioner is urging, but instead both because the Court is appropriately cautious in expanding liability under implied rights of action, and because Congress has now looked at this question, not once but twice, and has declined to provide secondary liability for secondary actors under the cause of action.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think that you are either a principal or an aider and abettor?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: You can... it's possible for someone to be both but in order to be both they must have... they must have satisfied all of the elements.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: For the same act, I'm talking about... for the same act.

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: Yes.
For instance an auditor who certifies false financial statements and allows--

that... its certification to be, to be publicly disseminated, thereby aiding and assisting in the issuer's primary fraud, but is also a... quite likely to be a primary violator, because they have spoken to the market.
The market is relying on their statements, and is aware that they are making them; and so they would be both a primary violator, but could presumably be pursued as an aider and abettor.
I don't think there is any preclusion of liability under both, but in order to be in that category you must be a primary violator.

And here, Petitioners have not established and cannot establish the reliance element with respect to Respondents, because nothing that Respondents said or did was disseminated to the market during the class period.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And I take it in your view they cannot establish the "in connection with" argument?

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: We have not taken a position--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Prior to the statment, there is no reliance, but that there is "in connection with"--

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --Your Honor, I would hesitate to say that, Your Honor, because the SEC and the United States do not have to establish reliance in criminal or--
civil enforcement proceedings, but we do have to establish "in connection with", and we think they are different.

We think reliance adds something more than what "in connection with" requires, and so I certainly would urge the Court not to suggest that merely because reliance is not established, therefore "in connection with" must not also be established; and that is one of the reasons why we think that the "in connection with" question is best resolved, not in this case, but in the case where it's been squarely presented, and preferably a government enforcement action where the government has an opportunity to tailor the case in an appropriate fashion.
The Court, as I said has been--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: It's at least a little awkward for you to say we should wait for a case in which it's been fully presented when the argument you're making here wasn't fully presented, or at least not decided below.

turn.speaker: thomas_g_hungar
turn.label: Mr. Thomas G. Hungar
turn.text: --I think it was, Your Honor.
It was certainly briefed and argued in both the district court and the court of appeals.
The district court squarely resolved it at page 41a of the petition appendix.
The court of appeals addressed reliance at page 10a of the petition appendix.
It did not give it a--
fully orbed discussion.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I understood the court of appeals' decision to be based on its determination that there was no deceptive act because there was no statement or omission.
